CatDescriptText: Related image published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, July 8, 1944, pg. 10.  Portions of accompanying article read: "Stanton-Taylor Marriage Unites Prominent Families, Pittsburgh, Pa. - In a ceremony that embodied beauty, solemnity and charming simplicity, Miss Marian Stanton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Stanton of Pittsburgh became the bride of Edward Victor Taylor, son of the late Robert R. Taylor, Sr., and Mrs. Taylor of Wilmington, N. C., Saturday, July 1 at Holy Cross Episcopal Church with Father Charles Levy officiating.  The bride, given in marriage by her father, wore a white satin gown with sweetheart neckline and a tulle veil attached to a coronet of lace.  Her bouquet was of white roses and orchids.  Attendants, all of whom wore white, were her sisters and close friends, including her sister Eva as maid of honor; sister Mrs. Elsie Stanton Cobb of Detroit, Mrs. Romaine Denning Lyons matrons of honor, and Miss Betty Brady, Mrs. Helen Douglass Bolden, Miss Alice Batch, of D. C., and Mrs. Jean Nelson Harvey of Philadelphia are bridesmaids.  Brother is best man.  The groom's brother, Robert R. Taylor of Chicago was best man.  Ushers included Dr. Joseph Robinson of Albany, N.Y.; P. L. Prattis, Wendell Stanton and Samuel Milai of Pittsburgh.  Tiny Patricia Prattis was flower girl... The bride is a graduate of the University of Pittsburgh and until her marriage, was a teacher in the Pittsburgh School system.  She is a member of AKA, the Debs About Town and the We'Uns.  The groom, who is a regional director of the Federal Social Security board in the East, is the son of the late vice-president and superintendent of industry of Tuskegee.  He has attended Tuskegee, Fisk (where he received his B.S.) the University of Chicago and Columbia..."
TitMainTitle: Bride Marian Stanton Taylor wearing long sleeved gown with pointed headpiece, and groom Edward Victor Taylor walking down aisle away from altar at Holy Cross Church, with James O. Dougan in pews on left in background
